intro: Vaccinium lamellatum, commonly known as the broad-leaf huckleberry, is a species of flowering plant in the Ericaceae family. It is native to the western United States and is characterized by its oval, leathery leaves and clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers. The plant produces edible berries that are typically blue-black in color and have a tart, acidic flavor. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and streamside areas. Vaccinium lamellatum plays an important ecological role by providing food for various wildlife species.
